channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: 10 writers win 2024 Whiting Awards for emerging authors
item.description: Each writer will receive $50,000 to help support their craft — one of largest awards granted to new authors.
item.content:encoded: Each writer will receive $50,000 to help support their craft — one of largest awards granted to new authors.
item.dc:creator: Meghan Collins Sullivan

item.title: Why are Young Men and Women in South Korea Drifting Apart Politically?
item.description:
While the ideological gender gap among young people is widening across the developed world, it is particularly alarming in South Korea. Experts are concerned about what it means for the country's future. Our reporter in Seoul examines the phenomenon.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
While the ideological gender gap among young people is widening across the developed world, it is particularly alarming in South Korea. Experts are concerned about what it means for the country's future. Our reporter in Seoul examines the phenomenon.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.

(Image credit: Chung Sung-Jun)
item.dc:creator: Se Eun Gong

item.title: Why anti-abortion advocates are reviving a 19th century sexual purity law
item.description: The Comstock Act is the latest front in the fight over reproductive rights. Here's what you need to know about the 1873 law and the consequences if it's enforced the way some conservatives would like.
item.content:encoded:
The Comstock Act is the latest front in the fight over reproductive rights. Here's what you need to know about the 1873 law and the consequences if it's enforced the way some conservatives would like.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kurtzleben

item.title: World Athletics will pay $50,000 to Olympic gold medalists in track and field events
item.description: The prizes, which will also go to the winners of the marathon and race walk, come as the Olympic Games have shifted away from amateurism. Many medalists already earn bonuses from their home countries.
item.content:encoded:
The prizes, which will also go to the winners of the marathon and race walk, come as the Olympic Games have shifted away from amateurism. Many medalists already earn bonuses from their home countries.

(Image credit: Matthias Hangst)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: Trump backed a federal abortion ban as president. Now, he says he wouldn't sign one
item.description: The former president has a long history of shifting - and at times confusing - stances on abortion rights.
item.content:encoded:
The former president has a long history of shifting - and at times confusing - stances on abortion rights.

(Image credit: Megan Varner)
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kurtzleben

item.title: Consumer Reports asks USDA to remove Lunchables from schools' lunch menus
item.description: The group found high levels of sodium and the presence of heavy metals in meal kits it tested. A Kraft Heinz spokesperson said all of its products meet strict safety standards.
item.content:encoded:
The group found high levels of sodium and the presence of heavy metals in meal kits it tested. A Kraft Heinz spokesperson said all of its products meet strict safety standards.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: Real-life 'Rosie the Riveters' reunite in D.C. to win the nation's top civilian honor
item.description: Rosie the Riveter became an iconic symbol of the millions of women who worked industrial jobs during WWII. Dozens, now in their 90s and 100s, are accepting a Congressional gold medal on their behalf.
item.content:encoded: Rosie the Riveter became an iconic symbol of the millions of women who worked industrial jobs during WWII. Dozens, now in their 90s and 100s, are accepting a Congressional gold medal on their behalf.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Seizures, broken spines and vomiting: Scientific testing that helped facilitate D-Day
item.description: Biomedical engineer Rachel Lance says British scientists submitted themselves to experiments that would be considered wildly unethical today in an effort to shore up the war effort.
item.content:encoded: Biomedical engineer Rachel Lance says British scientists submitted themselves to experiments that would be considered wildly unethical today in an effort to shore up the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: 6 months into war, Palestinians face high unemployment and a 'disastrous' economy
item.description: A Palestinian Authority official says there are around 700,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza who have gone six months without work since the war between Israel and Hamas began on Oct. 7.
item.content:encoded: A Palestinian Authority official says there are around 700,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza who have gone six months without work since the war between Israel and Hamas began on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: Biden is hosting Japan's Kishida. But the Nippon Steel deal is not on the agenda
item.description: President BIden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida Fumio announced efforts to strengthen military ties, as well as collaborations on space exploration and artificial intelligence.
item.content:encoded:
President BIden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida Fumio announced efforts to strengthen military ties, as well as collaborations on space exploration and artificial intelligence.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Deepa Shivaram
